awd_titl_txt: Sovereign Debt Auctions: Theory and Empirics
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

Governments finance part of their budgetary needs by selling bonds through sovereign debt auctions. The price at which they can sell these bonds play a critical role in determining their cost of financing deficits, their implementation of monetary policy, and even the extent to which they can successfully navigate macroeconomic shocks. These auctions commonly come in two forms - uniform-price auctions (UP), in which all bidders pay the same price for the bonds and discriminatory-price auctions (DP) in which all bidders pay what they bid. This project will explore the determinants of bond prices and how sensitive those prices are to available information about governments and about macroeconomic variables. The project will further look at how these different auction protocols affect the revenue of governments as well as the likelihood of debt crises and the exposure of bond prices to changing economic conditions. 

This research consists of two projects. The first project develops a tractable theoretical framework to understand investors' bidding behavior and information choices in response to different auction protocols. The project uncovers a theoretically relevant trade-off between these two protocols when information is asymmetric. On the one hand, UP auctions allow governments to obtain an average higher price for its bonds. On the other hand, this protocol increases the sensitivity of bond prices to demand shocks. The second project consists on exploring the testable implications of the model utilizing detailed auction data in a setting where auction protocols have changed intermittently for the same country and sovereign interest rates went through periods of high turbulence and periods of prolonged stability. The project will also digitize this data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Governments worldwide raise funds to face fiscal expenses by selling sovereign bonds in primary markets. The mechanism involves investors submitting bids on the amount of bonds they are willing to buy at a given price if those bonds were allocated. The bidders who offer a higher bid are the ones to whom are first allocated until the government raises the amount desired. The two protocols that dominate these auctions in the world are discriminatory price (DP for short in what follows), in which bidders pay the price they bid when buying the bonds, and uniform price auctions (UP in what follows), in which they pay the minimum price at which bonds are sold to all investors.

In these markets, investors are usually heterogeneously informed about the quality of the bonds (the likelihood that the government repays) and their quantity available (how many investors will participate in the auction). What is the best way for governments to raise funds? What is the role of asymmetric information in the performance of these auctions? We explore these questions both theoretically and empirically. 

We first show that heterogeneous information about bond quality is indeed a significant concern for investors participating in primary markets. We solve a model of discriminatory price auction and show that better-informed investors tend to buy more frequently without overpaying, which is a unique implication of information asymmetries among investors. We obtain a novel dataset of bidding behavior and results from Cetes in Mexico (these are short-term no-coupon domestically-denominated sovereign Mexican bonds) and show, using granular data from 2001, that these auctions strongly suggest the existence of asymmetric information. Furthermore, by disciplining the model quantitatively to match main data observations, we conclude that the concern of some participants in auctions is that some investors may learn quickly when a "disaster" is looming in terms of a sudden increase in the probability of default. This concern reduces the price the government can obtain through bonds. This paper has been published in the Journal of Political Economy.

We then extended the period to capture one of these disasters, which in the case of Mexico was the "Tequila Crisis" in 1995. We calibrated the model and showed that even though, in regular times, discriminatory auctions depress the price of bonds because of concerns of asymmetric information about the possibility of disaster, they also provide a sense of insurance that prevents prices from being very low when a disaster indeed happens. This paper has been published in the American Economic Association Papers and Proceedings.

In a third paper, we study investors' incentives to obtain additional information about the bonds and the implications for other countries. We found that when investors become worried about a country, they react by acquiring information or taking their investments to another country. However, in the second case, if they become more exposed to some other country, they also have more incentives to acquire information about that country. In this sense, problems in one country may induce information in different, even uncorrelated, countries, with the implication of exacerbating asymmetric information and depressing their bond prices as well. We document this novel form of contagion for the 2012 European Sovereign Debt Crisis, exploiting primary and secondary bond price data for Portugal, Italy, Germany, and France. This paper is forthcoming at the Review of Economic Studies.

Finally, we have finalized a draft that generalizes the study of auction protocols with endogenous asymmetric information about bond quality and quantity. This general setting allows us to compare uniform and discriminatory price auctions with asymmetric information in an equal setting. We show that discriminatory price auctions allow governments to obtain higher prices for bids submitted but discourage investors from submitting high bids in the first place. The opposite happens with uniform price protocols. 

We also show that the incentives to acquire information in discriminatory price auctions are higher since an investor is worried about buying too many bad bonds and overpaying for them. Since more information is embedded in prices in discriminatory price auctions, we should observe that the results in primary markets are predictive of change in secondary markets. We devise an empirical identification strategy to test this implication by comparing Mexican bonds that were auctioned using discriminatory pricing since 2001 (Bondes) with those that changed from discriminatory to uniform in 2017 (Cetes). Consistent with our model, we show that the second became less informative after the change.

Since we have crafted a general setting, we also propose a superior auction protocol that combines uniform and discriminatory elements and exploits the higher revenue gains from discrimination with the lower bidding distortions of uniform pricing, hence improving the possibilities of raising funds by governments. We plan to submit this paper soon.
